Hi "JUnit Headache" :-)

What you are describing sounds more like Design by=
 Contract (DBC) than TDD
(they are not mutually exclusive, by the way).

Ov=
erall, DBC hasn't gained much traction in the software world, for a bunch
o=
f reasons (some detailed here <http://www.jroller.com/page/cbeust/20021213>=

).

As for your approach, it suffers from a couple of drawbacks:

   - It =
violates the Don't Repeat Yourself principle:  the code for
   testing is r=
epeated in both the method and the test method
   - It forces developers to=
 write code in comments, which is easy to
   break.

This doesn't mean you =
shouldn't go ahead and do it:  learning by example is
what school projects =
are all about...

-- 
Cedric
http://testng.org

On 12/27/06, junitheadache =
<bohs01@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
>
> I am currently working o=
n auto generation of test cases for TDD for
> my honors year project. And w=
as considering modifying JUnit such
> that it will auto generate some test =
cases based values flagged by
> users.
>
> E.g.,
> Public boolean isLegalIn=
t(int x){
> /* input - 0 < x < 10, result - True*/
>
> }
> given a comment =
like the above will generate assert statements such
> as
> assertFalse(isLe=
galInt(0));
> assertTrue(isLegalInt(1));
> assertTrue(isLegalInt(9));
> ass=
ertFalse(isLegalInt(10));
>
> Thus, I am trying to locate the source code t=
hat generates the
> testclass template to implement the changes and I can't=
 seem to find
> it anywhere. Any help would be greatly appreciated thankyou=
.
>
> p.s I am currently working with Junit 3.8.1
